comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: Larry Mulligan was Big Tim's half brother. Can't figure out who Hicks is. Ignominious end, yes, but 25,000 turned out for his funeral. That's after his body went unrecognized for two weeks and he nearly ended up in potter's field. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timothy_Sullivan

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Mona, I have trouble reading the dates, but once someone like Wystan has found a date on the plate negative, then we can do a search of the New York Times to find out more. If we go to the advanced search funtion of the NYT archive, and knowing that Tim Sullivan is the most well known person in this group, let's search of "Tim Sullivan" from July 1, 1913 to July 31, 1913: query.nytimes.com/search/query?frow=0&n=10&srcht=... Then scan the headlines and dates together, and we see a headline "Big Tim Sullivan Returns Imroved; Presence of Politician on Imperator a Secret Until Ship Reaches ..." and dated July 17, 1913. Usually, we look for an article dated the day after the date on the negative, but there is no article for July 18, 1913 in this search. So let's try the one on July 17, 1913: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9904E5DD163DE633A... and here: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?_r=1&res=9904E... Neither of these articels exactly correlates with the date on the plate identified by Wystan, but we get a good idea of the fact that a sick Big Tim is back in town.

comment.author: 40147761@N04
comment._content: Ahh!  I'm learning.  Thank You again.

comment.author: 83025347@N00
comment._content: The story mentions that he was with his sister, Mrs. Hickey. So maybe that's Hicks? This would have been the maiden voyage of the Imperator, which left Cuxhaven on June 20 with stops at Cherbourg and Southampton, where Sullivan presumably boarded. At the time she was the largest passenger liner in service, and cruised at 23 knots. This would have been the height of trans-Atlantic luxury at the time. She was equipped with a swimming pool, and so much marble in the upper deck cabins that she was top heavy and suffered from stability problems. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/SS_Imperator
